sp.l: Aye, Aye, the Cords.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Ay me, what news?
Why dost thou wring thy hands.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Ah well-a-day, he is dead, he is dead,
we are undone Lady, we are undone.
Alack the day, he is gone, he is killed, he is dead.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Can heaven be so envious?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Romeo can,
Though heaven cannot. O Romeo, Romeo
Whoever would have thought it Romeo

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: What devil art thou,
that dost torment me thus?
This torture should be roared in dismal hell,
Hath Romeo slain himself? say thou but aye,
And that bare vowel I shall poison more
Than the death darting eye of Cockatrice,
I am not I, if there be such an I.
Or those eyes shot, that makes thee answer aye:
If he be slain say aye, or if not, no.
Brief, sounds, determine of my weal or woe.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes,
God save the mark, here on his manly breast,
A piteous Coarse, a bloody piteous Coarse:
Pale, pale as ashes, all bedaubed in blood,
All in gore blood, I sounded at the sight.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O break my heart,
Poor Bankrupt break at once,
to prison eyes, never look on liberty.
Vile earth to earth resign, end motion here,
And thou and Romeo press on heavy beer.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O Tybalt, Tybalt the best Friend I had:
O courteous Tybalt honest Gentleman,
that ever I should live to see thee dead.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What storm is this that blows so contrary?
Is Romeo slaughtered? and is Tybalt dead?
My dearest Cozen, and my dearer Lord:
Then dreadful Trumpet sound the general doom,
for who is living, if those two are gone:

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Tybalt is gone, and Rome banished,
Romeo that killed him, he is banished.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O God
Did Rom'os hand shed Tybalts blood
It did, it did, alas the day, it did.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O Serpent heart, hid with a flowering face.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Did ever Dragon keep so fair a Cave?
Beautiful Tyrant, fiend Angelicall:
Ravenous Dove feathered Raven,
Wolfish ravening Lamb,
Despised substance of Divinest show:
Just opposite to what thou justly seem'st,
A damned Saint, an Honourable Villain:
O Nature what hadst thou to do in hell,
When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend
in mortal paradise of such sweet flesh?
Was ever book containing such vile matter
so fairly bound? O that deceit should dwell
in such a gorgeous Palace.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: there is no trust, no faith, no honesty in men,
All perjured, all forsworn, all naught, all dissemblers,
Ah where is my man? give me some Aqua vitæ?
These griefs, these woes, these sorrows make me old:
Shame come to Romeo

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Blistered be thy tongue
for such a wish, he was not borne to shame:
upon his brow shame is ashamed to sit;
for it is a throne where Honour may be Crowned
Sole Monarch of the universal earth:
O what a beast was I to chide him?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: will you speak well of him,
that killed your Cozen?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Shall I speak ill of him that is my husband?
Ah poor my Lord, what tongue shall smooth thy name,
When I thy three hours' wife have mangled it.
But wherefore Villain didst thou kill my Cousin?
that Villain Cousin would have killed my husband:
back foolish tears, back to your native spring,
Your tributary drops belong to woe,
which you mistaking offer up to joy:
My husband lives that Tibalt would have slain,
And Tibalt dead that would have slain my husband:
All this is comfort, wherefore weep I then?
Some words there was worser than Tybalts death
that murdered me, I would forget it fain,
But o, it presses to my memory,
like damned guilty deeds to sinners minds,
Tybalt is dead and Romeo banished:
that banished, that one word banished,
Hath slain ten thousand Tibalts Tibalts death
Was woe enough if it had ended there:
Or if sour woe delights in fellowship,
And needly will be ranked with other griefs,
Why followed not when she said Tibalts dead,
Thy Father or thy Mother, nay or both,
which modern lamentation might have moved.
But which a rear ward following Tybalts death
Romeo is banished to speak that word,
Is Father, Mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Iuliet
All slain, all dead: Romeo is banished,
There is no end, no limit, measure, bound,
in that words death, no words can that woe sound.
Where is my Father and my Mother Nurse?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Weeping and wailing over Tybalts Coarse,
will you go to them? I will bring you thither.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Wash they his wounds with tears: mine shall be spent
When theirs are dry for Romeo's banishment,
Take up those Cords, poor ropes you are beguiled,
Both you and I for Romeo is exiled:
He made you for a high way to my bed,
But I a Maid, die Maiden widowed.
Come Cord, come Nurse, I will to my wedding bed,
And death not Romeo take my Maiden head.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Hie to your Chamber, I will find Romeo
to comfort you, I wot well where he is:
Hark ye your Romeo will be here at night,
I will to him, he is hid at Lawrence Cell.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O find him, give this Ring to my true Knight, And bid him come, to take his last farewell.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Romeo come forth,
Come forth thou fearful man,
Affliction is enamoured of thy parts:
And thou art wedded to calamity.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Father what news?
What is the Prince's Doom?
What sorrow craves acquaintance at my hand,
that I yet know not?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Too familiar
Is my dear son with such sour Company:
I bring thee tidings of the Prince's Doom.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What less than Doomsday,
Is the Prince's Doom?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: A gentler judgment vanished from his lips,
Not bodies death, but bodies banishment.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Ha, banishment? be merciful, say death:
for exile hath more terror in his look,
Much more than death: do not say banishment.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Here from Verona art thou banished:
Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: There is no world without Uerona walls,
But Purgatory, Torture, hell itself:
Hence banished, is banish: from the world,
And worlds exile is death. Then banished,
Is death, mistermed, calling death banished,
Thou cuttest my head off with a golden Axe,
And smilest upon the stroke that murders me.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: O deadly sin, O rude unthankfulness
Thy fault our Law calls death, but the kind Prince
Taking thy part, hath rushed aside the Law,
And turned that black word death, to banishment.
This is dear mercy, and thou seest it not.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: it is Torture and not mercy, heaven is here
Where Iuliet lives, and every Cat and Dog,
And little Mouse, every unworthy thing
live here in Heaven and may look on her,
But Romeo may not. More Validity,
More Honourable state, more Courtship lives
in carrion Flies, than Romeo they may seize
on the white wonder of dear Iuliets hand.
And steal immortal blessing from her lips,
who even in pure and vestal modesty
Still blush, as thinking their own kisses sin.
This may Flies do, when I from this must fly,
And sayst thou yet, that exile is not death?
But Romeo may not, he is banished.
hadst thou no poison mixed, no sharpe ground knife,
no sudden mean of death, though never so mean,
But banished to kill me? Banished?
O Friar, the damned use that word in hell:
Howlings attends it, how hast thou the heart
Being a Divine, a Ghostly Confessor,
A Sin Absolver, and my Friend professed:
to mangle me with that word, banished?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Then fond Mad man, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: O thou wilt speak again of banishment.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I will give thee Armour to keep off that word,
Adversities sweet milk, Philosophy,
to comfort thee, though thou art banished.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Yet banished? hang up Philosophy:
unless Philosophy can make a Iuliet
Displant a Town, reverse a Prince's Doom,
It helps not, it prevails not, talk no more.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: O then I see, that Mad men have no ears.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How should they,
When wisemen have no eyes?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Let me despair with thee of thy estate,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel,
Wert thou as young as Iuliet my love:
An hour but married, Tybalt murdered,
Doting like me, and like me banished,
Then mightst thou speak,
Then mightst thou tear thy hair,
And fall upon the ground as I do now,
Taking the measure of an unmade grave.

sp.speaker: Frier.
sp.l: Arise one knocks,
Good Romeo hide thyself.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Not I,
unless the breath of Heartsick groans
Mist-like enfold me from the search of eyes.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Hark how they knock:
who is there) Romeo arise,
Thou wilt be taken, stay a while, stand up:

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Run to my study: by and by, Gods will
What simpleness is this: I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: who knocks so hard?
Whence come you? what is your will?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Let me come in,
And you shall know my errand:
I come from Lady Iuliet

sp.speaker: Fri
sp.l: Welcome then.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O holy Friar, O tell me holy Friar,
where is my Ladies Lord? where is Romeo

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: There on the ground,
With his own tears made drunk.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O he is even in my Mistress case,
Just in her case. O woeful sympathy:
Piteous predicament even so lies she,
Blubbering and weeping, weeping and blubbering,
Stand up, stand up, stand and you be a man,
for Iuliets sake, for her sake rise and stand:
Why should you fall into so deep an O.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Ah sir, ah sir, death is the end of all.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Speakest thou of Iuliet how is it with her?
Doth not she think me an old Murtherer,
Now I have stained the Childhood of our joy,
With blood removed, but little from her own?
Where is she? and how doth she? and what says
My concealed Lady to our concealed love?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: o she says nothing sir, but weeps and weeps,
And now falls on her bed, and then starts up,
And Tybalt calls, and then on Romeo cries,
And then down falls again.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: As if that name shot from the dead level of a Gun,
Did murder her, as that names cursed hand
Murdered her kinsman. o tell me Friar, tell me,
in what vile part of this Anatomy
Doth my name lodge? Tell me, that I may sack
The hateful Mansion.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Hold thy desperate hand:
Art thou a man? thy form cries out thou art:
Thy tears are womanish, thy wild acts denote
The unreasonable Fury of a beast.
Unseemly woman, in a seeming man,
And ill beseeming beast in seeming both,
Thou hast amazed me. by my holy order,
I thought thy disposition better tempered.
hast thou slain Tybalt wilt thou slay thyself?
And slay thy Lady, that in thy life lies,
by doing damned hate upon thyself?
Why railest thou on thy birth? the heaven and earth?
Since birth, and heaven and earth, all three do meet
in thee at once, which thou at once wouldst loose.
Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape thy love, thy wit,
which like a Usurer aboundest in all:
And usest none in that true use indeed,
which should bedeck thy shape, thy love, thy wit:
Thy Noble shape, is but a form of wax,
Digressing from the Valour of a man,
Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury,
Killing that love which thou hast vowed to cherish.
Thy wit, that Ornament, to shape and love,
Misshapen in the conduct of them both:
like powder in a skilless Soldier's flask,
Is set a fire by thine own ignorance,
And thou dismembered with thine own defence.
What, rouse thee man, thy Iuliet is alive,
for whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead.
There art thou happy. Tybalt would kill thee,
But thou slewest Tybalt there art thou happy.
The law that threatened death became thy Friend,
And turned it to exile, there art thou happy.
A pack or blessing light upon thy back,
Happiness Courts thee in her best array,
But like a misshaped and sullen wench,
Thou puttest up thy Fortune and thy love:
Take heed, take heed, for such die miserable.
go get thee to thy love as was decreed,
Ascend her Chamber, hence and comfort her:
But look thou stay not till the watch be set,
for then thou canst not pass to Mantua
Where thou shalt live till we can find a time
to blaze your marriage, reconcile your Friends,
Beg pardon of thy Prince, and call thee back,
With twenty hundred thousand times more joy
Than thou wentest forth in lamentation.
go before Nurse, commend me to thy Lady,
And bid her hasten all the house to bed,
which heavy sorrow makes them apt unto.
Romeo is coming.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O Lord, I could have staid here all night,
to hear good counsel: o what learning is
My Lord I will tell my Lady you will come.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Do so, and bid my Sweet prepare to chide.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: here sir, a Ring she bid me give you sir:
Hie you, make haste, for it grows very late.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: How well my comfort is revived by this.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Go hence,
Goodnight, and here stands all your state:
Either be gone before the watch be set,
Or by the break of day disguised from hence,
Sojourn in Mantua I will find out your man,
And he shall signify from time to time,
every good hap to you, that chances here:
give me thy hand, it is late, farewell, goodnight.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: But that a joy past joy, calls out on me,
It were a grief, so brief to part with thee:
Farewell.

div1.stage: Enter old Capulet,his Wife and Paris.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Things have fallen out sir so unluckily,
that we have had no time to move our Daughter:
look you, she loved her kinsman Tybalt dearly,
And so did I. Well, we were borne to die.
it is very late, she will not come down tonight:
I promise you, but for your company,
I would have been a-bed an hour ago.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: These times of woe, afford no times to woo:
Madam goodnight, commend me to your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I will, and know her mind early tomorrow,
tonight, she is mewed up to her heaviness.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Sir Paris I will make a desperate tender
Of my Child's love: I think she will be ruled
in all respects by me: nay more, I doubt it not.
Wife, go you to her ere you go to bed,
Acquaint her here, of my son Paris love,
And bid her, mark you me, on Wednesday next,
But soft, what day is this?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Monday my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Monday, ha ha: well Wednesday is too soon,
A-Thursday let it be: a-Thursday tell her,
She shall be married to this Noble Earl:
will you be ready? do you like this haste?
we will keep no great ado, a Friend or two,
for hark you, Tybalt being slain so late,
It may be thought we held him carelessly,
Being our kinsman, if we revel much:
Therefore we will have some half a dozen Friends,
And there an end. But what say you to Thursday?

sp.speaker: Paris.
sp.l: My Lord,
I would that Thursday were tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Well, get you gone, a-Thursday, be it then:
Go you to Iuliet ere you go to bed,
Prepare her wife, against this wedding day.
Farewell my Lord, light to my Chamber ho,
Afore me, it is so late, that we may call it early by and by,
Goodnight.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day:
It was the Nightingale, and not the Lark,
that pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear,
Nightly she sings on yond Pomegranate tree,
Believe me love, it was the Nightingale.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: It was the Lark the Herald of the Morn:
no Nightingale: look love what envious streaks
Do lace the severing Clouds in yonder East:
night's Candles are burnt out, and Jocund day
Stands tiptoe on the misty Mountains' tops,
I must be gone and live, or stay and die.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yond light is not daylight, I know it I:
It is some Meteor that the Sun exhales,
to be to thee this night a Torch bearer,
And light thee on thy way to Mantua
Therefore stay yet, thou needst not to be gone,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Let me be taken, let me be put to death,
I am content, so thou wilt have it so.
I will say yon gray is not the morning's eye,
it is but the pale reflex of Cinthias brow.
Nor that is not Lark whose notes do beat
The vaulty heaven so high above our heads,
I have more care to stay, than will to go:
Come death and welcome, Iuliet wills it so.
How is it my soul, let us talk, it is not day.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: It is, it is, hie hence be gone away:
It is the Lark that sings so out of tune,
Straining harsh Discords, and unpleasing Sharps,
Some say the Lark makes sweet Division;
This doth not so: for she divides us.
Some say, the Lark and loathed Toad change eyes,
O now I would they had changed voices too:
Since arm from arm that voice doth us affray,
Hunting thee hence, with Hunts up to the day,
O now be gone, more light and it light grows.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: More light and light, more dark and dark our woes.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Your Lady Mother is coming to your chamber,
The day is broke, be wary, look about.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Then window let day in, and let life out.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Farewell, farewell, one kiss and I will descend.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Art thou gone so? love, Lord, ay Husband, Friend,
I must hear from thee every day in the hour,
for in a minute there are many days,
O by this count I shall be much in years,
Ere I again behold my Romeo

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Farewell:
I will omit no opportunity,
that may convey my greetings love, to thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O thinkest thou we shall ever meet again?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I doubt it not, and all these woes shall serve
for sweet discourses in our time to come.

sp.speaker: Iuilet.
sp.l: O God I have an ill Divining soul,
Methinks I see thee now, thou art so low,
As one dead in the bottom of a Tomb,
Either my eye sight sails, or thou lookest pale.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And trust me love, in my eye so do you:
Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O Fortune, Fortune, all men call thee fickle,
If thou art fickle, what dost thou with him
that is renowned for faith? be fickle Fortune:
for then I hope thou wilt not keep him long,
But send him back.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Ho Daughter are you up?

sp.speaker: Iul:
sp.l: who, is it that calls? Is it my Lady Mother.
Is she not down so late, or up so early?
What unaccustomed cause procures her hither?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: Why how now Iuliet

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam I am not well.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: ever more weeping for your Cousin's death?
What wilt thou wash him from his grave with tears?
And if thou couldst, thou couldst not make him live:
Therefore have done, some grief shows much of love,
But much of grief, shows still some want of wit.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yet let me weep, for such a feeling loss.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: so shall you feel the loss, but not the Friend
which you weep for.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Feeling so the loss,
I cannot choose but ever weep the Friend.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well Girl, thou weepest not so much for his death,
As that the Villain lives which slaughtered him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What Villain, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: that same Villain Romeo

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Villain and he, be many Miles asunder:
God pardon, I do with all my heart:
And yet no man like he, doth grieve my heart.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: that is because the Traitor lives.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Aye Madam from the reach of these my hands:
Would none but I might venge my Cousin's death.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: we will have vengeance for it, fear thou not.
Then weep no more, I will send to one in Mantua
Where that same banished Run-agate doth live,
Shall give him such an unaccustomed dram,
that he shall soon keep Tybalt company:
And then I hope thou wilt be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Indeed I never shall be satisfied
With Romeo till I behold him. Dead
Is my poor heart so for a kinsman vexed:
Madam if you could find out but a man
to bear a poison, I would temper it;
that Romeo should upon receipt thereof,
soon sleep in quiet. O how my heart abhors
to hear him named, and cannot come to him,
to wreak the love I bore my Cousin,
upon his body that hath slaughtered him.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Find thou the means, and I will find such a man.
But now I will tell thee joyful tidings Girl.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And joy comes well, in such a needy time,
What are they, beseech your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Well, well, thou hast a careful Father Child?
One who to put thee from thy heaviness,
Hath sorted out a sudden day of joy,
that thou expects not, nor I looked not for.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Madam in happy time, what day is this?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Marry my Child, early next Thursday morn,
The gallant, young, and Noble Gentleman,
The County Paris at Saint Peters Church,
Shall happily make thee a joyful Bride.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now by Saint Peters Church, and Peter too,
He shall not make me there a joyful Bride.
I wonder at this haste, that I must wed
Ere he that should be Husband comes to woe:
I pray you tell my Lord and Father Madam,
I will not marry yet, and when I do, I swear
It shall be Romeo whom you know I hate
Rather than Paris These are news indeed.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Here comes your Father, tell him so yourself,
And see how he will take it at your hands.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: When the Sun sets, the earth doth drizzle dew
But for the Sunset of my Brothers son,
It rains downright.
How now? A Conduit Girl, what still in tears?
Evermore showering in one little body?
Thou counterfeit a Bark, a Sea, a Wind:
for still thy eyes, which I may call the Sea,
Do ebb and flow with tears, the Bark thy body is
Sailing in this salt flood, the winds thy sighs,
who raging with the tears and they with them,
Without a sudden calm will overset
Thy tempest tossed body. How now wife?
have you delivered to her our decree?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Aye sir:
But she will none, she gives you thanks,
I would the fool were married to her grave.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Soft, take me with you, take me with you wife,
How, will she none? doth she not give us thanks?
Is she not proud? doth she not count her blessed,
Unworthy as she is, that we have wrought
so worthy a Gentleman, to be her Bridegroom

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Not proud you have,
But thankful that you have:
Proud can I never be of what I have,
But thankful even for hate, that is meant love.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How now?
How now? Chopped Logic? what is this?
Proud, and I thank you: and I thank you not.
thank me no thankings, nor proud me no prouds,
But settle your fine joints against Thursday next,
to go with Paris to Saint Peters Church:
Or I will drag thee, on a Hurdle thither.
Out you green sickness carrion, out you baggage,
You tallow face.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Fie, fie, what are you mad?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Good Father, I beseech you on my knees
hear me with patience, but to speak a word.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Hang thee young baggage, disobedient wretch,
I tell thee what, get thee to Church a-Thursday,
Or never after look me in the face.
speak not, reply not, do not answer me.
My fingers itch, wife: we scarce thought us blessed,
that God had lent us but this only Child,
But now I see this one is one too much,
And that we have a curse in having her:
Out on her Hilding.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: God in heaven bless her,
You are to blame my Lord to rate her so.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: And why my Lady wisdom? hold your tongue,
Good Prudence, smatter with your gossip, go.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: I speak no treason,
Father, O Godigoden,
May not one speak?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Peace you mumbling fool,
Utter your gravity over a Gossips bowls
for here we need it not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: You are too hot.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Gods bread, it makes me mad:
Day, night, hour, ride, time, work, play,
Alone in company, still my care hath been
to have her matched, and having now provided
A Gentleman of Noble Parentage,
Of fair Demeans, Youthful, and Nobly Allied,
Stuffed as they say with Honourable parts,
Proportioned as ones thought would wish a man,
And then to have a wretched puling fool,
A whining mammet, in her Fortunes tender,
to answer, I will not wed, I cannot love:
I am too young, I pray you pardon me.
But, if you will not wed, I will pardon you.
Graze where you will, you shall not house with me:
look to it, think on it, I do not use to jest.
Thursday is near, lay hand on heart, advise,
If you be mine, I will give you to my Friend:
If you be not, hang, beg, strove, die in the streets,
for by my soul, I will never acknowledge thee,
Nor what is mine shall never do thee good:
Trust to it, bethink you, I will not be forsworn

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.l: Is there no pity sitting in the Clouds,
that sees into the bottom of my grief?
O sweet my Mother cast me not away,
Delay this marriage, for a month, a week,
Or if you do not, make the Bridal bed
in that dim Monument where Tybalt lies.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: talk not to me, for I will not speak a word,
Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O God
O Nurse, how shall this be prevented?
My Husband is on earth, my faith in heaven,
How shall that faith return again to earth,
unless that Husband send it me from heaven,
by leaving earth? Comfort me, counsel me:
Alack, alack, that heaven should practise stratagems
upon so soft a subject as myself.
What sayst thou? hast thou not a word of joy?
Some comfort Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Faith here it is,
Romeo is banished, and all the world to nothing,
that he dares never come back to challenge you:
Or if he do, it needs must be by stealth.
Then since the case so stands as now it doth,
I think it best you married with the County,
O he is a Lovely Gentleman:
Romeo is a dish clout to him: an Eagle Madam
Hath not so green, so quick, so fair an eye
As Paris hath, beshrew my very heart,
I think you are happy in this second match,
for it excels your first: or if it did not,
Your first is dead, or it were as good he were,
As living here and you no use of him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Speakest thou from thy heart?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: And from my soul too,
Or else beshrew them both.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Well, thou hast comforted me marvelous much,
Go in, and tell my Lady I am gone,
having displeased my Father, to Lawrence Cell,
to make confession, and to be absolved.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Marry I will, and this is wisely done.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ancient damnation, O most wicked fiend
It is more sin to wish me thus forsworn,
Or to dispraise my Lord with that same tongue
which she hath praised him with above compare,
so many thousand times? Go Counsellor,
Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain:
I will to the Friar to know his remedy,
If all else fail, myself have power to die.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: on Thursday sir? the time is very short.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: My Father Capulet will have it so,
And I am nothing slow to slack his haste.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: You say you do not know the Ladies mind?
Uneven is the course, I like it not.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Immoderately she weeps for Tybalts death,
And therefore have I little talk of love,
for Venus smiles not in a house of tears.
Now sir, her Father counts it dangerous
that she doth give her sorrow so much sway:
And in his wisdom, hastes our marriage,
to stop the inundation of her tears,
which too much minded by herself alone,
May be put from her by society.
Now do you know the reason of this haste?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I would I knew not why it should be slowed.
look sir, here comes the Lady towards my Cell.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Happily met, my Lady and my wife.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: that may be sir, when I may be a wife.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: that may be, must be love, on Thursday next.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: What must be shall be.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: that is a certain text.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Come you to make confession to this Father?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: to answer that, I should confess to you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Do not deny to him, that you love me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will confess to you that I love him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: so will ye, I am sure that you love me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If I do so, it will be of more price,
Being spoke behind your back, than to your face.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Poor soul, thy face is much abused with tears.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: The tears have got small victory by that:
for it was bad enough before their spite.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Thou wrongest it more than tears with that report.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: that is no slander sir, which is a truth,
And what I spake, I spake it to thy face.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slandered it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It may be so, for it is not mine own.
Are you at leisure, Holy Father now,
Or shall I come to you at evening Mass?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: My leisure serves me pensive daughter now.
My Lord you must entreat the time alone.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: God shield: I should disturb Devotion,
Iuliet on Thursday early will I rouse ye,
Till then adieu, and keep this holy kiss.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O shut the door, and when thou hast done so,
Come weep with me, past hope, past care, past help.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: O Iuliet I already know thy grief,
It streams me past the compass of my wits:
I hear thou must and nothing may prorogue it,
on Thursday next be married to this County.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Tell me not Friar that thou hearest of this,
unless thou tell me how I may prevent it:
If in thy wisdom, thou canst give no help,
Do thou but call my resolution wise,
And with his knife, I will help it presently.
God joined my heart, and Romeos thou our hands,
And ere this hand by thee to Romeo sealed:
Shall be the Label to another Deed,
Or my true heart with treacherous revolt,
Turn to another, this shall slay them both:
Therefore out of thy long experienced time,
give me some present counsel, or behold
Twixt my extremes and me, this bloody knife
Shall play the umpire, arbitrating that,
which the commission of thy years and art,
Could to no issue of true honour bring:
Be not so long to speak, I long to die,
If what thou speakest, speak not of remedy.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Hold Daughter, I do spy a kind of hope,
which craves as desperate an execution,
As that is desperate which we would prevent.
If rather than to marry County Paris
Thou hast the strength of will to stay thyself,
Then is it likely thou wilt undertake
A thing like death to chide away this shame,
that copest with death himself, to escape from it:
And if thou darest, I will give thee remedy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: o bid me leap, rather than marry Paris
From off the Battlements of any Tower,
Or walk in thievish ways, or bid me lurk
Where Serpents are: chain me with roaring Bears
Or hide me nightly in a Charnel house,
Overcovered quite with dead men's rattling bones,
With reeky shanks and yellow chapel's sculls:
Or bid me go into a new made grave,
And hide me with a dead man in his grave,
Things that to hear them told, have made me tremble,
And I will do it without fear or doubt,
to hide an unstained wife to my sweet love.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Hold then: go home be merry, give consent,
to marry Paris wednesday is tomorrow,
tomorrow night look that thou lie alone,
Let not thy Nurse lie with thee in thy Chamber:
Take thou this Vial being then in bed,
And this distilling liquor drink thou off,
When presently through all thy veins shall run,
A cold and drowsy humour: for no pulse
Shall keep his native progress, but surcease:
no warmth, no breath shall testify thou livest,
The Roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade
to many ashes, the eyes windows fall
like death when he shut up the day of life:
Each part deprived of supple government,
Shall stiff and stark, and cold appear like death,
And in this borrowed likeness of shrunk death
Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,
And then awake, as from a pleasant sleep.
Now when the Bridegroom in the morning comes,
to rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:
Then as the manner of our country is,
in thy best Robes uncovered on the Beer,
Be borne to burial in thy kindreds grave:
Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault,
Where all the kindred of the Capulets lie,
in the mean time against thou shalt awake,
Shall Romeo by my Letters know our drift,
And hither shall he come, and that very night
Shall Romeo bear thee hence to Mantua
And this shall free thee from this present shame,
If no inconstant toy nor womanish fear,
Abate thy valour in the acting it.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: give me, give me, O tell not me of care.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Hold get you gone, be strong and prosperous:
in this resolve, I will send a Friar with speed
to Mantua with my Letters to thy Lord.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: love give me strength,
And strength shall help afford:
Farewell dear father.

div1.stage: Enter Father Capulet,Mother,Nurse,and Seruing men,two or three.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: so many guests invite as here are writ,
sirra, go hire me twenty cunning Cooks.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: You shall have none ill sir, for I will try if they can lick their fingers.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How canst thou try them so?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Marry sir, it is an ill Cook that cannot lick his own fingers: therefore he that cannot lick his fingers goes not with me.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Go be gone, we shall be much unfurnished for this time: what is my Daughter gone to Friar Lawrence

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Aye forsooth.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Well he may chance to do some good on her,
A peevish self wild harlotry it is.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: See where she comes from shrift
With merry look.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How now my headstrong,
Where have you been gadding?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Where I have learnt me to repent the sin
Of disobedient opposition:
to you and your behests, and am enjoined
by holy Lawrence to fall prostrate here,
to beg your pardon: pardon I beseech you,
Henceforward I am ever ruled by you.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Send for the County, go tell him of this,
I will have this knot knit up tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I met the youthful Lord at Lawrence Cell,
And gave him what becomed love I might,
Not stepping over the bounds of modesty.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why I am glad on it, this is well, stand up,
This is as it should be, let me see the County:
Aye marry go I say, and fetch him hither.
Now afore God, this reverend holy Friar,
All our whole City is much bound to him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nurse will you go with me into my Closet,
to help me sort such needful ornaments,
As you think fit to furnish me tomorrow?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: no not till Thursday, there is time enough.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Go Nurse, go with her,
we will to Church tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: we shall be short in our provision,
it is now near night.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Tush, I will stir about,
And all things shall be well, I warrant thee wife:
Go thou to Iuliet help to deck up her,
I will not to bed tonight, let me alone:
I will play the housewife for this once. What ho?
They are all forth, well I will walk myself
to County Paris to prepare him up
Against tomorrow, my heart is wondrous light,
Since this same way ward Girl is so reclaimed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Aye those attires are best, but gentle Nurse
I pray thee leave me to myself tonight:
for I have need of many Orisons,
to move the heavens to smile upon my state,
which well thou knowest, is cross and full of sin.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: What are you busy ho? need you my help?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: no Madam, we have culled such necessaries
As are behooveful for our state tomorrow:
so please you, let me now be left alone;
And let the Nurse this night sit up with you,
for I am sure, you have your hands full all,
in this so sudden business.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Goodnight.
Get thee to bed and rest, for thou hast need.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Farewell:
God knows when we shall meet again.
I have a faint cold fear thrills through my veins,
that almost freezes up the heat of fire:
I will call them back again to comfort me.
Nurse, what should she do here?
My dismal Scene, I needs must act alone:
Come Vial, what if this mixture do not work at all?
Shall I be married then tomorrow morning?
no no this shall forbid it. Lie thou there,
What if it be a poison which the Friar
Subtly hath ministered to have me dead,
lest in this marriage he should be dishonoured,
Because he married me before to Romeo
I fear it is, and yet methinks it should not,
for he hath still been tried a holy man.
How, if when I am laid into the Tomb,
I wake before the time that Romeo
Come to redeem me? there is a fearful point:
Shall I not then be stifled in the Vault?
to whose foul mouth no healthsome air breaths in,
And there die strangled ere my Romeo comes.
Or if I live, is it not very like,
The horrible conceit of death and night,
Together with the terror of the place,
As in a Vault, an ancient receptacle,
Where for these many hundred years the bones
Of all my buried Ancestors are packed,
Where bloody Tybalt yet but green in earth,
Lies festering in his shroud, where as they say,
At some hours in the night, Spirits resort:
Alack, alack, is it not like that I
so early waking, what with loathsome smells,
And shrikes like Mandrakes torn out of the earth,
that living mortals hearing them, run mad.
O if I walk, shall I not be distraught,
Environed with all these hideous fears,
And madly play with my forefathers joints?
And pluck the mangled Tybalt from his shroud?
And in this rage, with some great kinsman's bone,
As with a club) dash out my desperate brains.
O look, methinks I see my Cousin's Ghost,
Seeking out Romeo that did spit his body
upon my Rapiers point: stay Tybalt stay;
Romeo,Romeo,Romeo here is drink: I drink to thee.

div1.stage: Enter Lady of the house,and Nurse.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Hold,
Take these keys, and fetch more spices Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: They call for Dates and Quinces in the Pastry.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Come, stir, stir, stir,
The second Cock hath Crowed,
The Curfew Bell hath rung, it is three o'clock:
look to the baked meats, good Angelica
Spare not for cost.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Go you Cot quean, go,
Get you to bed, faith you will be sick tomorrow
for this night's watching.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: no not a whit: what? I have watched ere now
All night for less cause, and never been sick.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Aye you have been a Mouse hunt in your time,
But I will watch you from such watching now.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: A jealous hood, a jealous hood,
Now fellow, what there?

div1.stage: Enter three or foure with spits,and logs,and baskets.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Things for the Cook sir, but I know not what.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Make haste, make haste, sirra, fetch drier Logs.
Call Peter he will show thee where they are.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I have a head sir, that will find out logs,
And never trouble Peter for the matter.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Mass and well said, a merry whoreson, ha,
Thou shalt be loggerhead; good Father, it is day.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: The County will be here with Music straight,
for so he said he would, I hear him near,
Nurse, wife, what ho? what Nurse I say?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Go waken Iuliet go and trim her up,
I will go and chat with Paris hie, make haste,
Make haste, the Bridegroom, he is come already:
Make haste I say.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Mistress, what Mistress? Iuliet Fast I warrant her she.
Why Lamb, why Lady? fie you slugabed,
Why love I say? Madam, sweet heart: why Bride?
What not a word? You take your pennyworths now.
Sleep for a week, for the next night I warrant
The County Paris hath set up his rest,
that you shall rest but little, God forgive me:
Marry and Amen: how sound is she asleep?
I must needs wake her: Madam, Madam, Madam,
Aye, let the County take you in your bed,
he will fright you up yfaith. will it not be?
What dressed, and in your clothes, and down again?
I must needs wake you: Lady, Lady, Lady?
Alas, alas, help, help, my Lady is dead,
o well-a-day, that ever I was borne,
Some Aqua vitæ ho, my Lord, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: What noise is here?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O lamentable day.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: look, look, o heavy day.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: O me, O me, my Child, my only life:
Revive, look up, or I will die with thee:
Help, help, call help.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: for shame bring Iuliet forth, her Lord is come.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: she is dead: deceased, she is dead: alack the day.

sp.speaker: M.
sp.l: Alack the day, she is dead, she is dead, she is dead.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ha? Let me see her: out alas she is cold,
her blood is settled and her joints are stiff:
Life and these lips have long been separated:
Death lies on her like an untimely frost
upon the sweetest flower of all the field.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O Lamentable day

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: O woeful time.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Death that hath taken her hence to make me wail,
Ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Come, is the Bride ready to go to Church?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Ready to go, but never to return.
O son, the night before thy wedding day,
Hath death lain with thy wife: there she lies,
Flower as she was, deflowered by him.
Death is my son-in-law, death is my Heir,
My Daughter he hath wedded. I will die,
And leave him all life living, all is deaths.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: have I thought long to see this morning's face,
And doth it give me such a sight as this?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.l: Accursed, unhappy, wretched hateful day,
Most miserable hour, that ever time saw
in lasting labour of his Pilgrimage.
But one, poor one, one poor and loving Child,
But one thing to rejoice and solace in,
And cruel death hath catched it from my sight.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: O woe, O woeful, woeful, woeful day,
Most lamentable day, most woeful day,
that ever, ever, I did yet behold.
O day, O day, O day, O hateful day,
never was seen so black a day as this:
O woeful day, O woeful day.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Beguiled, divorced, wronged, spited, slain,
Most detestable death, by thee beguiled,
by cruel, cruel thee, quite overthrown:
O love, O life; not life, but love in death.

sp.speaker: Fat.
sp.l: Despised, distressed, hated, martyred, killed,
Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now
to murther, murther our solemnity?
O Child, O Child; my soul, and not my Child,
Dead art thou, alack my Child is dead,
And with my Child, my joys are buried.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Peace ho for shame, confusions: Care lives not
in these confusions, heaven and yourself
Had part in this fair Maid, now heaven hath all,
And all the better is it for the Maid:
Your part in her, you could not keep from death,
But heaven keeps his part in eternal life:
The most you sought was her promotion,
for it was your heaven, she shouldst be advanced,
And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced
above the Clouds, as high as Heaven itself?
O in this love, you love your Child so ill,
that you run mad, seeing that she is well:
she is not well married, that lives married long,
But she is best married, that dies married young.
Dry up your tears, and stick your Rosemarie
on this fair Coarse, and as the custom is,
And in her best array bear her to Church:
for though some Nature bids all us lament,
Yet Natures tears are Reasons merriment.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: All things that we ordained Festival,
Turn from their office to black Funeral:
our instruments to melancholy Bells,
our wedding cheer, to a sad burial Feast:
our solemn Hymns, to sullen Dirges change:
our Bridal flowers serve for a buried Coarse:
And all things change them to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Sir go you in; and Madam, go with him,
And go sir Paris everyone prepare
to follow this fair Coarse unto her grave:
The heavens do lower upon you, for some ill:
Move them no more, by crossing their high will.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: Faith we may put up our Pipes and be gone.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.l: Honest goodfellows: Ah put up, put up,
for well you know, this is a pitiful case.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: Aye by my troth, the case may be amended.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Musicians, o Musicians,
Hearts ease, hearts ease,
O, If you will have me live, play hearts ease.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: Why hearts ease;

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O Musicians,
Because my heart itself plays, my heart is full.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: Not a dump we, it is no time to play now.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You will not then?

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: no.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I will then give it you soundly.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: What will you give us?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: no money on my faith, but the gleek.
I will give you the Minstrel.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: Then will I give you the Serving creature.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Then will I lay the serving Creatures Dagger on your pate. I will carry no Crochets, I will Re you, I will Fa you, do you note me?

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: If you Re us, and Fa us, you Note us.

sp.speaker: 2.M.
sp.l: Pray you put up your Dagger,
And put out your wit.
Then have at you with my wit.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: I will dry beat you with an iron wit,
And put up my iron Dagger.
Answer me like men:
When griping griefs the heart doth wound, then Music with her silver sound.
Why silver sound? why Music with her silver sound? what say you Simon Catling

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: Marry sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pratest, what say you Hugh Rebicke

sp.speaker: 2.M.
sp.l: I say silver sound, because Musicians sound for silver

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Pratest too, what say you Iames Sound Post

sp.speaker: 3.Mu.
sp.l: Faith I know not what to say.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O I cry you mercy, you are the Singer.
I will say for you; it is Music with her silver sound,
Because Musicians have no gold for sounding:
Then Music with her silver sound, with speedy help doth lend redress.

sp.speaker: Mu.
sp.l: What a pestilent knave is this same?

sp.speaker: M.2.
sp.l: Hang him Jack, come we will in here, tarry for the Mourners, and stay dinner.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: If I may trust the flattering truth of sleep,
My dreams presage some joyful news at hand:
My bosom's lord sits lightly in his throne:
And all this day an unaccustomed spirit,
Lifts me above the ground with cheerful thoughts.
I dreamt my Lady came and found me dead,
Strange dream that gives a dead man leave to think,
And breathed such life with kisses in my lips,
that I revived and was an Emperor.
Ah me, how sweet is love itself possessed,
When but loves shadows are so rich in joy.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: News from Uerona how now Balthazer
Dost thou not bring me Letters from the Friar?
How doth my Lady? Is my Father well?
How doth my Lady Iuliet that I ask again,
for nothing can be ill, if she be well.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.
her body sleeps in Capels Monument,
And her immortal part with Angels live,
I saw her laid low in her kindreds Vault,
And presently took Post to tell it you:
O pardon me for bringing these ill news,
Since you did leave it for my office Sir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Is it even so?
Then I deny you Stars.
Thou knowest my lodging, get me ink and paper,
And hire Post Horses, I will hence tonight.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I do beseech you sir; have patience:
Your looks are pale and wild, and do import
Some misadventure.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Tush, thou art deceived,
Leave me, and do the thing I bid thee do.
hast thou no Letters to me from the Friar?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: no my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: more matter: Get thee gone,
And hire those Horses, I will be with thee straight.
Well Iuliet I will lie with thee tonight:
let us see for means: O mischief thou art swift,
to enter in the thoughts of desperate men:
I do remember an Apothecary,
And hereabouts dwells, which late I noted
in tattered weeds, with overwhelming brows,
Culling of Simples, meagre were his looks,
Sharpe misery had worn him to the bones:
And in his needy shop a Tortoise hung,
An Alligator stuffed, and other skins
Of ill shaped fishes, and about his shelves,
A beggarly account of empty boxes,
Green earthen pots, Bladders, and musty seeds,
Remnants of pack-thread, and old cakes of Roses
Were thinly scattered, to make up a show.
Noting this penury, to myself I said,
If a man did need a poison now,
Whose sale is present death in Mantua
Here lives a Caitiff wretch would sell it him.
O this same thought did but fore-run my need,
And this same needy man must sell it me.
As I remember, this should be the house,
Being holy day, the beggar's shop is shut.
What ho? Apothecary?

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: who calls so loud?

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Come hither man, I see that thou art poor,
Hold, there is forty Duckets, let me have
A dram of poison, such soon speeding gear,
As will disperse itself through all the veins,
that the life weary taker may fall dead,
And that the Trunk may be discharged of breath,
As violently, as hasty powder fired
Doth hurry from the fatal Canons womb.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Such mortal drugs I have, but Mantuas law
Is death to any he, that utters them.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Art thou so bare and full of wretchedness,
And fearest to die? Famine is in thy cheeks,
Need and oppression starveth in thy eyes,
Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back:
The world is not thy friend, nor the worlds law:
The world affords no law to make thee rich.
Then be not poor, but break it, and take this.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: My poverty, but not my will consents.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I pray thy poverty, and not thy will.

sp.speaker: App.
sp.l: Put this in any liquid thing you will
And drink it off, and if you had the strength
Of twenty men, it would dispatch you straight.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: there is thy Gold,
Worse poison to men's souls,
Doing more murther in this loathsome world,
Than these poor compounds that thou mayst not sell.
I sell thee poison, thou hast sold me none,
Farewell, buy food, and get thyself in flesh.
Come Cordial, and not poison, go with me
to Iuliets grave, for there must I use thee.

div1.stage: Enter Frier Iohn to Frier Lawrence.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Holy Franciscan Friar, Brother, ho?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: This same should be the voice of Friar Iohn
Welcome from Mantua what says Romeo
Or if his mind be writ, give me his Letter.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Going to find a bare foot Brother out,
One of our order to associate me,
Here in this City visiting the sick,
And finding him, the Searchers of the Town
Suspecting that we both were in a house
Where the infectious pestilence did reign,
Sealed up the doors, and would not let us forth,
so that my speed to Mantua there was staid.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: who bare my Letter then to Romeo

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I could not send it, here it is again,
Nor get a messenger to bring it thee,
so fearful were they of infection.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Unhappy Fortune: by my Brotherhood
The Letter was not nice, but full of charge,
Of dear import, and the neglecting it
May do much danger: Friar Iohn go hence,
Get me an Iron Crow, and bring it straight
unto my Cell.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Brother I will go and bring it thee.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Now must I to the Monument alone,
Within this three hours will fair Iuliet wake,
she will beshrew me much that Romeo
Hath had no notice of these accidents:
But I will write again to Mantua
And keep her at my Cell till Romeo come,
Poor living Coarse, closed in a dead man's Tomb,

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: give me thy Torch Boy, hence and stand aloft,
Yet put it out, for I would not be seen:
under yond young Trees lay thee all along,
Holding thy ear close to the hollow ground,
so shall no foot upon the Churchyard tread,
Being loose, unfirm with digging up of Graves,
But thou shalt hear it: whistle then to me,
As signal that thou hearest some thing approach,
give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I am almost afraid to stand alone
Here in the Churchyard, yet I will adventure.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Sweet Flower with flowers thy Bridal bed I strew:
O woe, thy Canopy is dust and stones,
which with sweet water nightly I will dew,
Or wanting that, with tears distilled by moans;
The obsequies that I for thee will keep,
Nightly shall be, to strew thy grave, and weep.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: The Boy gives warning, something doth approach,
What cursed foot wanders this ways tonight,
to cross my obsequies, and true loves right?
What with a Torch? Muffle me night a while.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: give me that Mattock, and the wrenching Iron,
Hold take this Letter, early in the morning
See thou deliver it to my Lord and Father,
give me the light; upon thy life I charge thee,
Whatever thou hearest or seest, stand all aloof,
And do not interrupt me in my course.
Why I descend into this bed of death,
Is partly to behold my Ladies face:
But chiefly to take thence from her dead finger,
A precious Ring: a Ring that I must use,
in dear employment, therefore hence be gone:
But if thou jealous dost return to pry
in what I further shall intend to do,
by heaven I will tear thee joint by joint,
And strew this hungry Churchyard with thy limbs:
The time, and my intents are savage wild:
More fierce and more inexorable far,
Than empty Tigers, or the roaring Sea.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I will be gone sir, and not trouble you

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: so shalt thou show me friendship: take thou that,
live and be prosperous, and farewell good fellow.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: for all this same, I will hide me here about,
His looks I fear, and his intents I doubt.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death,
Gorged with the dearest morsel of the earth:
Thus I enforce thy rotten Jaws to open,
And in despite, I will cram thee with more food.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This is that banished haughty Mountague
that murdered my loves Cousin; with which grief,
It is supposed the fair Creature died,
And here is come to do some villainous shame
to the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.
Stop thy unhallowed toil, vile Mountague
Can vengeance be pursued further than death?
Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee.
Obey and go with me, for thou must die,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I must indeed, and therefore came I hither:
Good gentle youth, tempt not a desperate man,
Fly hence and leave me, think upon those gone,
Let them affright thee. I beseech thee Youth,
Put not another sin upon my head,
by urging me to fury. O be gone,
by heaven I love thee better than myself,
for I come hither armed against myself:
Stay not, be gone, live, and hereafter say,
A mad man's mercy bid thee run away.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I do defy thy commiseration,
And apprehend thee for a Felon here.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Wilt thou provoke me? Then have at thee Boy.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: O Lord they fight, I will go call the Watch.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: O I am slain, if thou be merciful,
Open the Tomb, lay me with Iuliet

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: in faith I will, let me peruse this face:
Mercutius kinsman, Noble County Paris
What said my man, when my betossed soul
Did not attend him as we rode? I think
He told me Paris should have married Iuliet
Said he not so? Or did I dream it so?
Or am I mad, hearing him talk of Iuliet
to think it was so? O give me thy hand,
One, writ with me in sour misfortunes book.
I will bury thee in a triumphant grave.
A Grave; O no a Lantern; slaughtered Youth:
for here lies Iuliet and her beauty makes
This Vault a feasting presence full of light.
Death lie thou there, by a dead man interred.
How oft when men are at the point of death,
have they been merry? which their Keepers call
A lightning before death? o how may I
Call this a lightning? O my love, my Wife,
Death that hath sucked the honey of thy breath,
Hath had no power yet upon thy Beauty:
Thou are not conquered: Beauties ensign yet
Is Crimson in thy lips, and in thy cheeks,
And Deaths pale flag is not advanced there.
Tybalt liest thou there in thy bloody sheet?
O what more favour can I do to thee,
Then with that hand that cut thy youth in twain,
to sunder his that was thy enemy?
Forgive me Cozen. Ah dear Iuliet
Why art thou yet so fair? I will believe,
Shall I believe, that unsubstantial death is amorous?
And that the lean abhorred Monster keeps
Thee here in dark to be his Paramour?
for fear of that, I still will stay with thee,
And never from this Palace of dim night
Depart again: come lie thou in my arms,
here is to thy health, wherever thou tumblest in.
O true Apothecary
Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.
Depart again; here, here will I remain,
With Worms that are thy Chambermaids: O here
will I set up my everlasting rest:
And shake the yoke of inauspicious stars
From this world wearied flesh: Eyes look your last:
Arms take your last embrace: And lips, O you
The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss
A dateless bargain to engrossing death:
Come bitter conduct, come unsavoury guide,
Thou desperate Pilot, now at once run on
The dashing Rocks, thy Sea sick weary Bark:
here is to my love. O true Apothecary:
Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Saint. Francis be my speed, how oft tonight
have my old feet stumbled at graves? who is there?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: here is one, a Friend, and one that knows you well.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Bliss be upon you. Tell me good my Friend
What Torch is yond that vainly lends his light
to grubs, and eyeless Sculls? As I discern,
It burneth in the Capels Monument.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: It doth so holy sir,
And there is my Master, one that you love.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: who is it?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Romeo.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: How long hath he been there?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Full half an hour.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Go with me to the Vault.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I dare not Sir.
My Master knows not but I am gone hence,
And fearfully did menace me with death,
If I did stay to look on his intents.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Stay, then I will go alone, fears comes upon me.
O much I fear some ill unlucky thing.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: As I did sleep under this young tree here,
I dreamt my master and another fought,
And that my Master slew him.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Romeo.
Alack, alack, what blood is this which stains
The stony entrance of this Sepulchre?
What mean these Masterless, and gory Swords
to lie discoloured by this place of peace?
Romeo o pale: who else? what Paris too?
And steeped in blood? Ah what an viand hour
Is guilty of this lamentable chance?
The Lady stirs.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O comfortable Friar, where is my Lord?
I do remember well where I should be:
And there I am, where is my Romeo

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I hear some noise Lady, come from that nest
Of death, contagion, and unnatural sleep,
A greater power than we can contradict
Hath thwarted our intents, come, come away,
Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead:
And Paris too: come I will dispose of thee,
Among a Sisterhood of holy Nuns:
Stay not to question, for the watch is coming.
Come, go good Iuliet I dare no longer stay.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Go get thee hence, for I will not away,
what is here? A cup closed in my true lord's hand?
Poison I see hath been his timeless end
O churl, drink all? and left no friendly drop,
to help me after, I will kiss thy lips,
Haply some poison yet doth hang on them,
to make me die with a restorative.
Thy lips are warm.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Lead Boy, which way?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yea noise?
Then I will be brief. O happy Dagger.
it is in thy sheath, there rust and let me die

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: This is the place,
There where the Torch doth burn

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: The ground is bloody,
Search about the Churchyard.
Go some of you, whoever you find attach.
Pitiful sight, here lies the County slain,
And Iuliet bleeding, warm and newly dead
who here hath lain these two days buried.
Go tell the Prince, run to the Capulets
Raise up the Mountagues some others search,
we see the ground whereon these woes do lie,
But the true ground of all these piteous woes,
we cannot without circumstance descry.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: here is Romeo's man,
we found him in the Churchyard.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Hold him in safety, till the Prince come hither.

sp.speaker: 3.Wat.
sp.l: Here is a Friar that trembles, sighs, and weeps
we took this Mattock and this Spade from him,
As he was coming from this Church yard side.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A great suspicion, stay the Friar too.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: What misadventure is so early up,
that calls our person from our morning's rest?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What should it be that they so shrike abroad?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O the people in the street cry Romeo
Some Iuliet and some Paris and all run
With open outcry toward our Monument.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What fear is this which startles in your ears?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Sovereign, here lies the County Paris slain,
And Romeo dead, and Iuliet dead before,
Warm and new killed.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Search,
Seek, and know how, this foul murder comes.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Here is a Friar, and Slaughtered Romeos man,
With Instruments upon them fit to open
These dead men's Tombs.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O heaven
O wife look how our Daughter bleeds
This Dagger hath mistaken, for lo his house
Is empty on the back of Mountague
And is missheathed in my Daughters bosom.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: O me, this sight of death, is as a Bell
that warns my old age to a Sepulchre.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Come Mountague for thou art early up
to see thy son and Heir, now early down.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Alas my liege, my wife is dead tonight,
Grief of my sons exile hath stopped her breath:
What further woe conspires against my age?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: look: and thou shalt see.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: O thou untaught, what manners in is this,
to press before thy Father to a grave?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Seal up the mouth of outrage for a while,
Till we can clear these ambiguities,
And know their spring, their head, their true descent,
And then will I be general of your woes,
And lead you even to death? mean time forbear,
And let mischance be slave to patience,
Bring forth the parties of suspicion.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I am the greatest, able to do least,
Yet most suspected as the time and place
Doth make against me of this direful murther:
And here I stand both to impeach and purge
myself condemned, and myself excused.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Then say at once, what thou dost know in this?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: I will be brief, for my short date of breath
Is not so long as is a tedious tale.
Romeo there dead, was husband to that Iuliet
And she there dead, that is Romeos faithful wife:
I married them; and their stolen marriage day
Was Tybalts Doomsday: whose untimely death
Banished the new made Bridegroom from this City:
for whom and not for Tybalt Iuliet pined.
You, to remove that siege of Grief from her,
Betrothed, and would have married her perforce
to County Paris Then comes she to me,
And with wild looks) bid me devise some means
to rid her from this second Marriage,
Or in my Cell there would she kill herself.
Then gave I her so Tutored by my Art)
A sleeping Potion, which so took effect
As I intended, for it wrought on her
The form of death. Mean time, I writ to Romeo
that he should hither come, as this dire night,
to help to take her from her borrowed grave,
Being the time the Potions force should cease.
But he which bore my Letter, Friar Iohn
Was stayed by accident; and yesternight
Returned my Letter back. Then all alone,
At the prefixed hour of her waking,
Came I to take her from her Kindreds vault,
Meaning to keep her closely at my Cell,
Till I conveniently could send to Romeo
But when I came some Minute ere the time
Of her awaking) here untimely lay
The Noble Paris and true Romeo dead.
she wakes, and I entreated her come forth,
And bear this work of Heaven, with patience:
But then, a noise did scar me from the Tomb,
And she too desperate) would not go with me,
But as it seems) did violence on herself.
All this I know, and to the Marriage her Nurse is privy:
And if aught in this miscarried by my fault,
Let my old life be sacrificed, some hour before the time,
unto the rigour of severest Law.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: we still have known thee for a Holy man.
where is Romeo's man? What can he say to this?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I brought my Master news of Iuliets death,
And then in post he came from Mantua
to this same place, to this same Monument.
This Letter he early bid me give his Father,
And threatened me with death, going in the Vault,
If I departed not, and left him there.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: give me the Letter, I will look on it.
Where is the Counties Page that raised the Watch?
Sirrah, what made your Master in this place?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: He came with flowers to strew his Ladies grave,
And bid me stand aloof, and so I did:
Anon comes one with light to ope the Tomb,
And by and by my Master drew on him,
And then I ran away to call the Watch.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: This Letter doth make good the Friar's words,
Their course of love, the tidings of her death:
And here he writes, that he did buy a poison
Of a poor Apothecary, and therewithal
Came to this Vault to dye, and lie with Iuliet
Where be these Enemies? Capulet, Mountague
See what a scourge is laid upon your hate,
that Heaven finds means to kill your joys with love;
And I, for winking at your discords too,
have lost a brace of Kinsmen: All are punished.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: O Brother Mountague give me thy hand,
This is my Daughter's jointure, for no more
Can I demand.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: But I can give thee more:
for I will raise her Statue in pure Gold,
that whilst Uerona by that name is known,
There shall no figure at that Rate be set,
As that of True and Faithful Iuliet

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: As rich shall Romeo by his Lady lie,
Poor sacrifices of our enmity.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: A glooming peace this morning with it brings,
The Sun for sorrow will not show his head;
Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things,
Some shall be pardoned, and some punished.
for never was a Story of more Woe,
Than this of Iuliet and her Romeo
